info.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 10 at 5:42PM EDT by NWS Charleston
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of southeast South Carolina, including the following counties, Berkeley and Charleston. * WHEN...Until 700 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 534 PM EDT, showers and thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall were located from Hollywood, across Downtown Charleston, and into portions of Mount Pleasant. Between 3 and 5 inches of rain have fallen across portions of West Ashely, North Charleston, Daniel Island, and Mount Pleasant. An additional 1 to 2 inches are possible across the advisory area, with an isolated 2 to 3 inches possible across portions of John and James Islands. High tide will peak around 6 PM, resulting in slow draining of rain water on urban streets. High rainfall rates have been observed with these showers and thunderstorms and will likely cause roads in Downtown Charleston to quickly flood and possibly impassible. In addition, rapid rises have been observed at Church Creek near West Ashely. At around 530 PM water levels were observed a little over 4 feet and steadily rising. Flood stage is 5.5 feet. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... North Charleston, Mount Pleasant, Goose Creek, Hanahan, West Ashley, Downtown Charleston, James Island, I-26/I-526 Interchange, Johns Island, Daniel Island, Fort Sumter, Hollywood, Isle Of Palms, Folly Beach, Ravenel, Sullivan`s Island, Meggett, Charles Towne Landing, Maybank Bridge and James Island County Park.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Heavy rain in Downtown Charleston will result in nuisance flooding of low-lying areas. Areas most prone to flooding include the Market, Crosstown, East Bay Street and Morrison Drive. Slow down when traveling and allow extra distance between you and the vehicle ahead. Do not drive into water of unknown depth.
